document.docAuthor: Singh, Navneet, Volynkin, Anton V., Kirti, Jagbir Singh, Datta, Harvinder Singh & Ivanova, Maria S.
document.masterDocTitle: A review of the genus Cyana Walker, 1854 from India, with descriptions of five new species and three new subspecies (Lepidoptera: Erebidae: Arctiinae: Lithosiini)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A review of the genus Cyana Walker, 1854 from India, with descriptions of five new species and three new subspecies (Lepidoptera: Erebidae: Arctiinae: Lithosiini)

subSubSection.paragraph:
Bizone peregrina Walker, 1854
, List of the specimens of lepidopterous insects in the collection of the British Museum 2 : 551 ( Type locality: “ Ceylon ”).

= Chionaema peregrina
form. arguta Draudt, 1914 , in Seitz, Die Grossschmetterlinge der Erde 10: 168 ( Type locality: [S India , Kerala , Peermade] “Pirmád”).

Type material examined. Lectotype
of
Bizone peregrina Walker
(designated herein) ( Fig. 49 ): ♀ , handwritten label “ Ceylon . Colombo. (Nietner) 57–48” / printed label “7.
BIZONE PEREGRINA
.” / printed round label with a green circle “Type” / printed label with a unique identifier “NHMUK010402066” (Coll. NHMUK );
holotype
of
Chionaema peregrina
form. arguta Draudt ( Fig. 46 ): ♂ , printed label “Travancore. Peermade. Mrs. Imray.1904–226.” /
Chionaema peregrina
(handwritten) ab. (printed) arguta Draudt (handwritten) Holotype . Hampson Ab. (printed) I (handwritten)” / printed round label with a red circle “Type” / printed label with a unique identifier “NHMUK010402067” (Coll. NHMUK ).

Remarks . 1. In the original description, Walker (1854) mentions numerous specimens from various localities, which are syntypes . Hampson (1900) cited as ‘type’ specimens from Ceylon . In order to stabilize the nomenclature, we designate the specimen from Ceylon ( Sri Lanka ) deposited in NHMUK and labeled as ‘type’ as lectotype , and fix the species’ type locality as Ceylon . 2.
Singh et al. (2019b)
described a form of
C. peregrina
, which is lacking the chocolate colour patch on hindwing.

Diagnosis . Forewing length is 11–12 mm in males and 13–13.5 mm in females.
Cyana peregrina
is a sister species of
C. catorhoda
. Both species are variable in their forewing shape and width of forewing transverse lines and can be separated by the genitalia structures. In the male genitalia of
C. peregrina
, the valva is slightly broader than that of
C. catorhoda
, and the distal diverticulum is smaller and membranous (larger and granulated in
C. peregrina
). The female genitalia of
C. peregrina
are similar to those of
C. catorhoda
, but can be distinguished by the larger appendix bursae and longer band-like signum.

Distribution . Sri Lanka ( Hampson 1900 ), South and East India (
Singh et al. 2014
). The records for Thailand and Cambodia ( Černý & Pinratana 2009 ; Bayarsaikhan & Bae 2016 ) belong to
C. catorhoda .
